The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Devadatta is not only ungrateful and unappreciative now, but also from the past he has been ungrateful and unappreciative.
You should listen well, I will explain it for you.
The summary verse says:
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Long ago, not far from this great village near the city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a large forest with lush flowers, fruits, flowing springs, and bathing pools.
There was a sage named KauÅ›ika living in that forest, who would eat only fallen fruits, and wear tree bark for clothing;
his mind was filled with great compassion, and various birds and beasts all relied on him.
There was a female elephant in the forest who, when about to give birth, heard the lion's roar and was so frightened that she defecated and urinated, abandoned her child, and ran out of the forest.

At that time, the sage was picking fruit and saw the little elephant cub, knowing that it had lost its mother. The sage gave rise to a compassionate mind and pitied the elephant cub. He searched for its mother but could not find her, so he took the elephant cub to his dwelling place and raised it as if it were his own child.
As it gradually grew up, it destroyed the flowers and trees in the sage's dwelling.
When the sage saw this, he scolded it. The elephant knew that the sage was angry and no longer damaged the forest.
The elephant gradually grew larger and its mind became extremely violent. Later, it again damaged the forest. The sage scolded it again, but the elephant was not afraid.
The sage became even more angry, and the elephant gave rise to a harmful mind and wanted to trample the sage.
The sage ran into his room, and the elephant used its trunk and tusks to damage half of the sage's house and then ran away by itself.
At that time, the tree spirit in the forest spoke a verse, saying:
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The sage of that time is now me.
The elephant of that time is now Devadatta.
As he was ungrateful then, he is also so now, without any good retribution. You should know this!
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Devadatta also has a history of ingratitude and lack of repayment.
Listen carefully!
In the past, in this city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a king named MahÄÅ›akra, whose country was prosperous and whose people were all happy.
The king had a queen named CandraprabhÄ, whose dreams always came true.
In that country, there was a bodhisattva who was the king of deer. His body was golden in color, exceptionally handsome, and people never tired of seeing him.
Knowing his own handsomeness, he was always afraid, constantly hiding his body in fear of hunters.
At that time, the birds and beasts could understand each other's language. There was a crow who went to the king of deer and gave rise to loving thoughts, saying:
'Uncle!
Why are you frightened and eating grass?
' The golden deer king then replied:
'I am handsome, and all the hunters, if they see me, fear they will kill me. For this reason, eating grass, my mind is always frightened.'
The crow then said:
'At night, I am also afraid of the owl. We and our uncle, from now on, will guard each other.
If during the daytime, I am in a tall tree, inspecting good and bad, and reporting matters to the king.
If it reaches night, the king should observe and report matters to me.'
In that country, there was a great river beside the forest. At that time, there were two people who had previously had enmity, and suddenly met each other.
One man was stronger and bound the enemy, throwing him into the river. The current was swift and the man was drowning, so he said:
Who can save me? I will be your slave.
At that time, the deer king and his five hundred followers came to the river to drink water. Hearing this voice, with a compassionate mind, he entered the water to save the drowning man.
At that time, an old crow came to the king and said:
This black-headed worm has no gratitude or righteousness at all. Do not try to save him. If he escapes danger, he will certainly harm the deer king.
But the deer king, out of compassion, did not heed the crow's words. He went to the drowning man, carried him on his back, and brought him out.
When they reached the shore, he untied the rope with his mouth and waited for him to recover. Then he said:
Son, you should know that this is the way back. You should go well.
At that time, the drowning man knelt and joined his palms, and said to the deer king:
'I have obtained this life again from the king, and I wish to always serve as a slave to repay the king's kindness.'
Then the deer king spoke a verse, saying:
I do not need you as a slave, nor do I require your service;
Just do not say you saw me, lest he take my skin.
I now seek one more thing from you. If you follow my wish and do not say you saw me, that is repaying my kindness.
Why is that?
My body is dignified and endowed with excellent features. Fearing that person will know to kill me for my skin, therefore do not say you saw me here.
That person replied:
I respectfully follow the king's wish. I definitely will not say anything.
He then rose, joined his palms, circumambulated three times to the right, made obeisance, and left.

At that time, Queen Moonlight, having enjoyed the five desires and become exhausted, fell asleep. In the latter part of the night, she dreamed of a golden-colored deer king, sitting on a lion throne, expounding the profound Dharma to the kings of various countries and the masses.
While dreaming, she thought:
'The dream I had must be true.'
Delighted, she awoke and told the king about the dream she had seen.
When the king heard about the dream, he was astonished:
'How could a deer be sitting on a lion throne expounding the Dharma to the assembly?'
Then, Queen Moonlight spoke delightful words to the king, and the king was overjoyed. He then earnestly requested the king to find the golden-colored deer.
The king ordered his ministers to summon all the hunters in the country.
The ministers obeyed the order, summoned the hunters, and brought them to the king.
The king asked the hunters:
'I have heard that there is a golden deer in the country. Have you seen it?
If anyone has seen it, tie it with a soft rope without harming it, and bring it to me.'
The hunters said to the king:
'We have been hunting for many years, but we have never seen or heard of such a deer.
Great King, since you have heard of it, where is the deer?
Please catch it for the king.'
The king ordered his ministers to beat the drum and proclaim:
'If anyone has seen it, come and report to me, and I will give them five hundred villages as a reward.'
The ministers received the order, beat the drum, assembled the people, and proclaimed the king's generous reward.
At that time, the drowning man heard the king's generous offer and thought to himself:
'I am now poor and destitute. Should I greedily seek the king's generous reward?
Or should I repay his kindness and not speak of the deer?'
The Buddha told the monks:
It is a common law in the world that all beings, bound by the five desires, commit all kinds of evil.
At that time, the drowning man, greedy for the five desires, thought of the time when he was captured by the enemy.
He further thought:
'I now want to repay the enemy for his kindness, not fearing the future suffering as before, I should repay his enmity.'
Having thought this, he went to the palace gate and saw various adornments in accordance with the king's righteous law. The gatekeeper reported to the great king.
When the king heard this, he immediately called him in. The man reported to the king:
'In the mountains and forests, there are various flowers and fruits.
There is a king of deer with a golden-colored body surrounded by a thousand deer, extremely handsome.
I know his location and will allow the king to see him.'
When the king heard this, he was overjoyed. He summoned the ministers and led his troops. The foreign visitors, seeing the king's solemn procession, also followed along.
The man led them to the location of the king of deer and surrounded it with troops.
At that time, the crow friend of the deer king was always in a tall tree, and from afar saw the soldiers coming closer to the forest.
The crow then descended from the tree and said to the deer king:
The person who was previously drowning is the one who betrayed your kindness. The king does not need to save him, and he did not listen to my words.
The deer king asked:
What is the reason?
The crow replied to the deer king:
The person who was drowning previously is leading soldiers to hunt the deer king.
At that time, the thousand deer heard the sound of the soldiers and fled in fright.
At that time, the deer king had this thought:
If I run now, the soldiers will search for me and also kill the thousand deer;
I would rather die myself and save the thousand deer.

Having had this thought, at that time the deer king went to where the king was. The person who had previously been drowning saw from afar the deer king and immediately raised two fingers to point at the king, saying:
The golden deer king, he is coming.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
If sentient beings create extremely evil karma, they will experience the consequences in this very life, not waiting for the next life.
The drowning man, due to not knowing gratitude and creating evil karma, his fingers turned into antlers, and his hands immediately fell to the ground.
The king saw this and asked in wonder:
'Why did this suddenly happen, with both hands falling off?'
At that time, the drowning man, in pain and tears, replied to the king with a verse, saying:
'One who breaks through walls and steals is not called a thief;
One who is ungrateful is called a great thief.'
The king heard these words and asked the man:
'What is the meaning of this verse?
I do not understand now.'
At that time, the drowning man then explained the previous matter in detail to the king.
When the king heard this, he spoke a verse in reply to the drowning man who did not know gratitude, saying:
Why does your body not sink into the earth?
Why does your tongue not split into a hundred parts?
Why do the vajra-wielding beings not kill you?
Why do all the ghosts and spirits not strike you?
Why do you receive so little retribution for your extreme ingratitude?
The king knew that the deer was a great bodhisattva with great authority and virtue, and he told his ministers:

We should make great offerings to the king of deer. You should quickly return and sweep the roads, hang silk banners and canopies, and burn various famous fragrances. I will accompany the king of deer and come into the city together.
The ministers heard the decree and fully followed the king's instructions.

At that time, the king of the country ordered the golden-colored deer to walk in front, and the king and his ministers followed behind the king of deer, entering the city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«. In front of the palace gate, they set up a lion throne, adorned with various decorations, and invited the king of deer to sit.
The king, Queen Moonlight, the palace ladies, princes, and people surrounded and sat down.

At that time, the deer king was expounding the wonderful Dharma. After the king, queen, and all the great assembly had heard the Dharma, they requested the deer king to accept the five precepts, and all sentient beings vowed to return to bodhi.
Seeing this, the king was greatly delighted and said to the deer king:
'The mountains, forests, and wilderness where the king roams are all given to the deer king.
From now on, I will permanently abstain from killing, and I will also prevent the people of the country from hunting. I wish all sentient beings to be fearless in their abodes.'
The Buddha told the monks:
The deer king at that time is now me.
The ungrateful person at that time is now Devadatta.
In the past, he was ungrateful, and now it is the same.
The Buddha told the monks:
Devadatta also has the practice of being ungrateful and not repaying kindness.
You all listen attentively!

In the past, in a village on the outskirts of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a man who made flower garlands. Next to the village, there was a river. The man who made flower garlands always crossed the river to pick flowers.

Later, at one time, he wanted to cross the river. In the river, he obtained an untimely mango fruit. He took it to the royal city and gave it to the gatekeeper. The gatekeeper obtained it and passed it on to the messenger.
The messenger obtained it and immediately presented it to the king. The king obtained the fruit and gave it to the queen. The queen obtained the fruit and immediately ate it.
Because the fruit was fragrant and delicious, she asked the king for more. The king again asked the messenger:
Where did you obtain the fruit?
The messenger replied:

The king then sent for the gatekeeper and asked:

The garland maker replied:
'I found it in the river.'
The king told the garland maker:
'Go to the river and look for more of these fruits.'
After the garland maker received the order, he took his own provisions and went back to the river. Following the water, he went to a mountain and from a high cliff, he saw the fruit tree.
The cliff was steep and dangerous, and all the monkeys could not climb up, let alone humans.
The garland maker searched for many days, but there was no way to climb up. His provisions were also exhausted. He thought to himself:
'I received the king's order to find the fruit. Now that I have not obtained it, how can I return?

Having had this thought, disregarding his own life, he climbed up the steep cliff with his hands, gradually ascending, but before reaching the fruit, he fell down. There was a deep pit below, into which he fell.

At that time, there was a bodhisattva who was the king of the monkeys, roaming in the mountains and valleys. He saw the person wearing a flower garland fallen into a deep pit, suffering from hunger and hardship.

The bodhisattva gave rise to the thought of saving all sentient beings, skillfully devising a plan. The monkey king then took a large stone, weighing it to be the same as a person, and immediately carried it on his back, practicing and turning around, knowing he could get out of the pit. He then carried the garland person out, gradually escaping.
Because of this, he became tired and his body became exhausted.
At that time, all the birds and beasts understood human language.
The monkey king asked the person wearing the flower garland:
Why did you fall into the deep pit?
The person wearing the flower garland explained in detail as above.
At that time, the bodhisattva had this thought:
'This fruit-picker will not get any fruit and will certainly be punished.
I should now take some mango fruit for him.'
Although the Bodhisattva was exhausted, he climbed up the high cliff, picked the fruit, and threw it to the garland-maker.
Having obtained it, he ate to his heart's content, and stored the remaining fruit in his robe.
The monkey descended from the tree and said to the garland-maker,
'I am now tired and want to sleep for a while. You should be on alert and guard me.'
The garland-maker replied,
'Good!
I will be on alert.'
The monkey then fell asleep.
At that time, the garland-maker had this thought:
'My provisions are exhausted. If I eat the fruit, what will I offer to the king?
I should kill the monkey, dry it, and use it as provisions for the journey, then I will be able to get there.
At that time, the evil person, not knowing gratitude, gave rise to evil thoughts, picked up a large rock, hit the monkey on the head, shattered the bones and marrow, and finally took its life.
At that time, a god in the sky, having seen this, immediately spoke a verse, saying:
Serving and respecting, like a good friend;
There are such people who do not know to repay kindness.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

The evil person Flower Garland is now Devadatta.
Not only did he not know to repay kindness in the past, but he is also like this now.
Bhiká¹£us should know.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Devadatta also has the conduct of not being grateful and not repaying kindness.
You should listen carefully!
In the past, there was a mountain forest with various flowers and fruits.
At that time, there was a bird named Woodpecker. On one side of the forest, there was a lion king who usually killed deer for food.
Later, after killing a deer, he ate it. A bone got stuck in his throat and he could not get it out. He suffered for a long time and could not eat, becoming emaciated and hungry.
The bird was playing and saw the lion king, so he asked:
Uncle!
Why are you so emaciated?
The lion replied:
I have pain.
The bird asked:
Why do you have pain?
The lion king explained in detail as above.
The bird said again:
I will treat your pain. You are the king of beasts. Can you repay my kindness?
Give me food every day.
The lion king replied:
I can always provide according to your needs.
The bird then thought:
'I will devise a plan to remove the bone, and only then will I let him know.'
'I will wait until the lion is asleep before I can remove the bone.'
Having thought this, he briefly roamed the tree in search of food.
At that time, the lion king, encountering a cool breeze, fell into a beautiful sleep.
When the bird saw that he was asleep, he used a piece of wood to pry open his mouth and carefully examined it. He then entered the mouth, grabbed the bone, and came out.
He was on the tree, waiting for the lion king to wake up from his sleep, and then he would show him the bone.
At that time, the lion king woke up from his nap in an instant, and he realized that the bone in his throat was gone and he was no longer in pain. He squatted and yawned.
The bird saw this with joy, flew down from the tree and showed him the bone, reporting to the lion, saying:
'Uncle!
The pain is all because of this bone.'
The lion rejoiced and reported to the bird, saying:
'Nephew!
I have been in pain for a long time, but now I have been cured. I want to make offerings and serve you for the rest of my life.'
'Please, nephew,
come here every day.'
Hearing these words, the woodpecker was delighted and left.

Later, when the lion king was just about to eat the deer, the woodpecker was chased by a hawk, frightened and starving, and flew to the lion, saying, 'I am being chased by a hawk and am starving and frightened. Please, uncle, give me a meal.'
Then the lion king replied in verse:
I shall go forth to kill, with an evil nature and evil conduct;
My teeth are sharp, if you enter my mouth, you may come out;
You should be happy, what else do you seek now?
Hearing these words, the woodpecker also replied in verse:
What falls into the ocean is lost, what is obtained in a dream is lost when one wakes up;
Serving evil people is lost;
Saving ungrateful people is even more lost, what do I seek from you?
After the bird spoke the verse, it flew away.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The woodpecker king at that time was none other than I myself.
The ungrateful lion king was none other than Devadatta.
In the past he did not know gratitude and did not know to repay kindness, and now it is the same.
You should know this!
The World-Honored One further told the bhiká¹£us:
Devadatta also has the conduct of being ungrateful and not repaying kindness.
You should listen carefully!
In the past, in the city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a poor man who always made a living by collecting firewood to sell.
At one time, he took a rope and an ax and went to the edge of the forest, intending to cut firewood.

He happened to encounter a violent storm out of season, which did not cease for seven days. To avoid the wind and rain, he gradually passed through and finally reached the side of a mountain, where he saw a stone cave and wanted to enter it.
Just as he was about to reach the entrance of the cave, he saw a bear inside and was frightened and ran away.
Seeing him run away in fear, the bear called out to him, saying:ğŸ”½Why do you run away in fear upon seeing me?
'Good man, come!
Do not be afraid of me.'
Although the man heard the bear's call, he was still terrified and stood there hesitating, neither going forward nor retreating.
Seeing him standing there, the bear embraced him into the cave, not letting him be frightened, and gave him delicious fruits and edible tree roots to sustain him for seven days until the eighth day.
The bear himself went out to check the wind and rain. Seeing the wind and rain stop, he gave him delicious fruits and sent him off.
The man knelt for a long time with palms joined and said:
'I have been provided for and my life has been saved. From now on, how can I repay your kindness?'
The bear then replied:
'If you just do not tell outsiders that I live here, that will be repaying my kindness.'
The man then circumambulated the bear once and said to the bear:
'I will never dare to tell others.'
Having said this, he left immediately.
The man went to the city gate of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« and saw a hunter who was about to go hunting. They had known each other before.
The hunter asked:
You haven't returned home for many days, and your wife, children, and relatives are all worried, saying:
Were you swept away by wind and rain, or eaten by tigers and wolves?
They think you're dead.
Many animals have died in the great rain, so how are you still alive?
The man who gathered firewood then told the story of how the bear raised him, as explained above.
The hunter asked:
In which mountain and which cave is that bear now?
I wish you would show me.
The man who gathered firewood replied to the hunter:
Even if I die now, I still cannot go back into the mountains and forests.
The hunter said many skillful words and various exhortations:
If I kill it, I will give you a large share, and I will take a small share.
The man then gave rise to greedy thoughts, turned back, and looked at the bear's location as he walked to the entrance of the cave, pointing at the bear from afar.
At that time, the hunter piled up firewood at the entrance of the cave and smoked it with fire.
At that time, the bear was tormented by the smoke and fire, and was about to die. He then spoke a verse, saying:
I have lived in this mountain, not harming a single person;
Eating fruits and tree roots, always giving rise to thoughts of compassion.
Now my life is about to end, what plan should I make again?
I think of my past karma, good and evil, now I receive the retribution.
When the bear had spoken this verse, he immediately died.
At that time, the hunter knew that the bear was dead, so he entered the cave, took the bear's skin, and divided it into three parts. He said to the woodcutter:
You take two parts of the meat, and I'll take one part.
At that time, the wood gatherer used his hand to take the flesh. When he took the flesh, both hands fell off. The hunter saw this and exclaimed:
How strange!
How strange!
The hunter's own flesh was also not taken away, so he returned to the city and reported this extraordinary event to the king, telling the people of the country what had happened.

When the king heard this, he personally went to see it. He collected the bear's skin and went to the temple. He struck the bell to assemble the assembly, and then placed the bear's skin in front of the assembly of monks.

After the king had paid homage to the monks, he told the assembly of monks about the above events. The senior monk in the temple had attained the fruit of arhatship and replied to the king of the country in verse, saying:
Great king, you should know that this is not the body of a real bear;
This is a supreme bodhisattva who will attain the unsurpassed fruit.
He should be worshipped by the three worlds. Great king, you should build a stupa.

When the king heard this, he ordered his ministers to take various fragrant woods, go to the bear's cave, burn his body, build a stupa, place various flowers and incense, hang silk banners and canopies, sprinkle and sweep to make offerings.
The king, ministers, and people all made an agreement to gather together every year to make offerings.
After making the agreement, they circumambulated the stupa and left.
All the people who came to pay homage to the stupa and make offerings would all be reborn in the heavens.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The bear of the past is now my body.
The evil man who gathered firewood then is now Devadatta.
In the past he was already ungrateful and unappreciative, and now he is also ungrateful and shameless.
You should know this.
At that time the World-Honored One again told the bhiká¹£us:
Devadatta also has the conduct of being ungrateful and unappreciative.
You should listen carefully!
In the past, in the city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a poor man who always made a living by collecting firewood.

Later, at one time, he took a rope and an axe to the mountains and forests. He came to a tree and wanted to collect firewood. He happened to encounter a large tiger. He was frightened and ran away, climbing up a large tree.
He did not realize that there was a bear in the tree. Seeing it, he was even more afraid and did not dare to climb any higher.
The bear saw that he was frightened and gradually came down to tell him:
You don't need to be afraid!
Just rely on me.
The woodcutter heard this but still did not dare to approach.
The bear saw that he was pitiful and came himself to embrace him. On the tree, he chose a safe place and sat there, holding him.
At that time, under the tree, the large tiger told the bear:
This is an ungrateful being. Later, he will harm you. Why do you need to protect him?
You should throw him down from the tree. I need to eat him;
if I don't get to eat him, I will never leave.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
In the ways of the world, if someone takes refuge, one still protects them, let alone a bodhisattva who has someone take refuge and does not protect them?
At that time, the bear said to the tiger:
'This person has taken refuge in me, I will never go against my word.'
The tiger, hearing these words, was unwilling to leave because of hunger and exhaustion.
The bear said to the woodcutter:
'I am now exhausted from carrying you, I will sleep for a while. You should be on guard and protect me.'
With his head resting on the woodcutter, he immediately gave rise to thoughts:
'I will temporarily rest and sleep, and for the woodcutter I will speak ten verses of the Dharma.'
Having had this thought, the bear immediately fell asleep.
The tiger, seeing the bear asleep, said to the woodcutter:
'How long can you stay up in the tree?
You should throw the bear down to the ground, I will eat and then leave, sparing you from harm and allowing you to return home.'
At that time, the woodcutter, hearing these words, immediately gave rise to evil thoughts:
'This worm speaks well. How long can I stay here?'
Having thought this, he threw the bear down from the tree and pushed it down. Before it even reached the ground, it spoke the ten secret syllables. After speaking, it reached the ground.
When the worm got the bear, it ate it to its fill and then left.
The woodcutter heard the bear speak the ten secret syllables of the Dharma and thought:
'The bear has good Dharma and should speak to me.'
He then gave rise to greed and affliction. Because of losing the Dharma, his mind became confused and he ran around.
He spoke the ten secret syllables.
At that time, the woodcutter's relatives saw that he was insane. They took him home. He only spoke the ten secret syllables and nothing else.
The relatives, seeing that he was insane, sought out doctors and skilled spell-casters. Various medical methods could not cure him.
Not far from the city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a forest with many fruits. Many birds gathered there and produced beautiful sounds.
At that time, in the forest there was a sage with the five supernatural powers. The relatives of the insane person brought him to see the sage, knelt and paid homage, and then said:
Our relatives are insane and confused, not speaking anything else but these ten words. We do not understand how to cure them.
The sage replied:

This person has committed evil and does not know gratitude at all. He killed a great bodhisattva and threw him under a tree, but before he reached the ground, he spoke ten words in between, to gather ten verses. After speaking these ten words, he fell to the ground and died, and was eaten by a tiger. At that time, the woodcutters became insane.
Then the relatives and disciples of the sage all said to the sage:
What are the ten verses?
What is their meaning?
At that time, the sage explained in order and spoke a verse.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
You should know!
The bear of the past is now my body.
The woodcutter who did not know gratitude at that time is now Devadatta.
In the past he did not know gratitude, and now it is the same.
You all should know this.
At that time the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
This Devadatta also has the conduct of being ungrateful and not repaying kindness.
You all listen carefully!
In the past there was a city called ÅšÄntÄ, and in it there was a king also named ÅšÄnta.
The country was prosperous and the people were at peace and happy, with no thieves or robbers and no wars with other states.

The king was compassionate by nature, regarding all sentient beings with pity as if they were his only child. He loved to give generously and always enjoyed listening to the Dharma. He was not stingy or greedy, and made offerings to Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and the poor and sick without ever being satisfied.
It was the king's constant practice to first visit his parents and then see to the sick before attending to the affairs of state every morning.
At that time, there was a poor man who was gravely ill and in extreme distress. The doctors who examined him refused to give him medicine, all saying he was certain to die.
When the sick person heard this, he was filled with sorrow and grief. He wandered about in tears until he reached the city of Peace and Tranquility.

At that time, the king, in the spring season, together with his ministers, consorts, and retinue, was going out to a garden to play. As he approached the city gate, the sick person, leaning on a cane and weeping, knelt and bowed before the king, saying:
I only wish, Great King, that you would save me, save me from this illness and suffering, and allow me to regain my life.
When the king saw this, he gave rise to great compassion, turned his carriage around, and returned to the palace, ordering a great minister:
Summon all the doctors in our country.
The minister, receiving the king's order, then immediately summoned all the doctors and brought them to see the king.
The king called for the sick person and personally examined him:
You doctors must treat him and cure him.
The doctors, having seen him, said to the great king:
